Am I the only one amazed by the launch and landing clip shown of SN9? Not so much the belly flop, which was like you said, spectacular. Rather the contrast in views of what we see at the SpaceX launch facility today compared to what the video showed as the ship crashed to Earth.

The launch took place in February of 2021. Now, here we are just 11 months later and the amount of work completed at Boca Chica boggles the mind. The launch tower is up, the launch table is on top of its legs, catch arms (chopsticks) are attached, the GSE tank farm nearing 100% completion (just testing needs to be completed from the looks of things), the QD arm is attached and boosters are being produced faster than they can test them.

I am so amazed.

I am still disappointed that there has been no launches in the last 7 months but I am anticipating a great new year of rocket enthusiasts.

Loved the quiz and look forward to reviewing the answers with you this time next year.

To be completely fair, having no flight milestones doesn't necessarily mean the same as none of the above. Boeing may have had flight milestones they wanted to achieve, but realized they weren't realistically going to get anywhere close,  so pushed those milestones to the next year. That's not the same as having them on the schedule and being so poor at the development thing that they missed every estimation on their time-line. Honestly, with their track record automation systems and taking development shortcuts, having no milestones scheduled because of needing to recheck everything they've already cleared as being ready is pretty realistic.

Tim, the only known answer to your former questions are two. First, you don't know how to do a correct survey. You've likely never learned how to create a designed survey that is professional and not full of fallacy. Second, you and commenters have never learned how to predict, where errors usually are created in predictions. These are skilled abilities not guessing games.

What you are is a reporter. Indeed, just a modern reporter.

I don't like your Astro Award either. It's cheap looking and embodies a government model that was dependent on a flawed system of bureaucracy and corporate/political pandering. Your award should instead support imagination, inspiration and forward thinking, not backward thinking. Are we headed to bold new ideas or more years of government wasteful programs like SLS and secret military spying? What is the Astro Award goal?

I bet for a growing opposition against Starlink in the future, as the European Agency already had to maneuver their own scientific satellites a few times to avoid collision with a starlink satellite, while the Chinese also had to move their station twice to avoid a potential collision. They even complained to the UN via UNOOSA.
Starlink just isn't viable and will put SpaceX in trouble in the future.

I think Starship will take much more time then anticipated, when SpaceX will almost get bankrupt because of Starlink, the Staship program might be on the verge of collapsing. SpaceX will be forced by the United States Congress to revise Starlink downwards or to give up the project of a giant constellation altogether. Starship will eventually be saved through government fundings and private investments. I think it'll succeed at launching Astronauts to the Moon at the some point in the early 2030s. The Chinese might be able to do the same thing at around the same time.
